title: How Tiger Woods statistically proves to be the best.
text:
Within the world of golf, greatness has been up for debate for years.
When bantering in a popular discussion of who is the greatest golfer of all time, it is apparent one player stands out compared to everyone else: Tiger Woods. Metrics can display clear evidence of dominant performances that can help lay the argument to rest from the statistical standpoint. While some stats are impressive, others prove to be untouchable.
To conceptualize how ahead Tiger is compared to other previously or currently ranked No. 1 players on a table, Wikipedia pulled data from the Official World Golf Rankings (OWGR) of golfers and their weeks at the top. Another table from Wikipedia also looked at each of the four majors’ archived statistics of previous winners.
Combining both of those together, it’s apparent how far ahead Tiger was in the peak of his career. The players listed are players that were No. 1 after 1997 which was the year when Tiger first touched the top.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(gt)

weeks <- read_csv("worldnumberonegolfers.csv") |> 
  separate(player, into=c("player", "dontknow"), sep="\\(") |> 
  mutate(player = str_trim(player)) |> 
  mutate(totalweeks = gsub("(record)", "", totalweeks, fixed=TRUE)) |> 
  mutate(totalweeks = gsub("[a]", "", totalweeks, fixed=TRUE)) |>   
  group_by(player) |>
  summarize(
    total_career_weeks = sum(as.numeric(totalweeks))
  ) 


majors <- read_csv("majors.csv") |> mutate(player = gsub("*", "", player, fixed=TRUE))



majorandweek <- weeks |> inner_join(majors)


golfer <- c("Adam Scott", "Brooks Koepka", "David Duval", "Dustin Johnson", "Ernie Els", "Jason Day", "Jon Rahm", "Jordan Spieth", "Justin Rose", "Justin Thomas", "Jordan Kaymer", "Rory McIlroy", "Scottie Scheffler", "Tiger Woods", "Vijay Singh" )

newmajorandweek <- majorandweek |>
  filter(player %in% golfer)|>
  select(player, total_career_weeks, total_major_wins) |>
  arrange(desc(total_career_weeks)) |>
  mutate_at(vars(-player), as.numeric)
  

newmajorandweek |> 
  gt() |>
  cols_label(
    player = "Player",
    total_career_weeks = "Weeks at No. 1",
    total_major_wins = "Total Major Titles"
  ) |>
  tab_header(
    title = "Tiger Woods' Dominance by the Numbers",
    subtitle = "Tiger Woods has nearly tripled the second highest amount of weeks as a No. 1 Golfer."
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  ) |>
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Jenna Gustafson | **Source:** Official World Golf Ranking")
  ) |>
  tab_style(
     locations = cells_column_labels(columns = everything()),
     style = list(
       cell_borders(sides = "bottom", weight = px(3)),
       cell_text(weight = "bold", size=10)
     )
   ) |>
  opt_row_striping() |>
  opt_table_lines("none") |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "#18453B"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = player == "Tiger Woods")
  )








Tiger Woods' Dominance by the Numbers


Tiger Woods has nearly tripled the second highest amount of weeks as a No. 1 Golfer.


Player
Weeks at No. 1
Total Major Titles




Tiger Woods
2511
15


Dustin Johnson
668
2


Rory McIlroy
562
4


Scottie Scheffler
230
2


Jon Rahm
154
2


Vijay Singh
87
3


Brooks Koepka
61
5


Jason Day
56
1


Jordan Spieth
37
3


Justin Rose
34
1


David Duval
29
1


Ernie Els
15
4


Adam Scott
11
1


Justin Thomas
9
2



By: Jenna Gustafson | Source: Official World Golf Ranking








Tiger’s reign was not only explosive, but it was extremely consistent. His performances give data-driven evidence that his accomplishments will be hard to bypass.
If reading the numbers didn’t fully capture how ahead Tiger is, then a visual most likely can. Transforming the table into a patchwork chart will clearly show the scale of dominance.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(patchwork)
library(gt)

golfer <- c("Adam Scott", "Brooks Koepka", "David Duval", "Dustin Johnson", "Ernie Els", "Jason Day", "Jon Rahm", "Jordan Spieth", "Justin Rose", "Justin Thomas", "Jordan Kaymer", "Rory McIlroy", "Scottie Scheffler", "Tiger Woods", "Vijay Singh" )

 newweeks <- weeks |>
  filter(player %in% golfer) 
  
 newmajors <- majors |>
   filter(player %in% golfer) |>
   select(player, total_major_wins)
 
 tigerweeks <- newweeks|>
   filter(player == "Tiger Woods")
 
 tigermajors <- newmajors |>
   filter(player == "Tiger Woods")


weekbar<- ggplot() +
  geom_bar(data=newweeks, aes(x=reorder(player, total_career_weeks), weight= total_career_weeks), fill = "lightgrey") +
 geom_bar(data=tigerweeks, aes(x=reorder(player, total_career_weeks), weight= total_career_weeks), fill = "#18453B") +
   coord_flip()+
  labs( 
    x= "",
    y= "Total Weeks at No. 1") +
  theme_minimal() 


majorbar <- ggplot() +
  geom_bar(data=newmajors, aes(x=reorder(player, total_major_wins), weight = total_major_wins), fill = "lightgrey") +
  geom_bar(data=tigermajors, aes(x=reorder(player, total_major_wins), weight = total_major_wins), fill="#18453B") +
  coord_flip()+
   labs( 
    x= "",
    y= "Total Major Titles") +
  theme_minimal() 


weekbar + majorbar +
  plot_annotation(
    title = "Tiger Woods' Dominance Through Visuals",
   subtitle = "Reference just how far ahead Tiger is vs. everyone else. ",
    caption = "Source: Official World Golf Ranking | By: Jenna Gustafson"
  ) &
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=13), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
    )









“But younger players like Scottie Scheffler haven’t been playing golf as long as Tiger Woods.”
Scheffler should undeniably be credited for his outstanding performances because he’s bringing an intense level of talent and success to the game of golf at as he is younger in in his career. Scheffler’s game may be “hot” right now, but that isn’t comparable to the consistency Tiger had.
Since comparing career accomplishments is unfair because every golfer is at a different stage in their career, it is important to look at the level of success each player has had in their careers so far through their winning percentages. It levels the playing field since not every player has played the same amount of tournaments.


Code
library(waffle)
library(gt)



tiger <- c("Win Percentage"= 22, "Non-Win Percentage" = 78)
scottiescheffler <- c("Win Percentage"= 10, "Non-Win Percentage" = 90)
rorymcilroy <- c("Win Percentage"= 11, "Non-Win Percentage" = 89)
jordanspieth <- c("Win Percentage"= 5, "Non-Win Percentage" = 95)
jasonday <- c("Win Percentage"= 4, "Non-Win Percentage" = 96)
adamscott <- c("Win Percentage"= 3, "Non-Win Percentage" = 97)
 


iron(
waffle(
  tiger,
  rows = 5,
  colors = c("#18453B", "lightgrey")
) +
  labs(
    title = "Players' Win Percentage",
    subtitle = "Tiger unsurprisingly doubles the second highest winning percentage which is Rory McIlroy's.",
    x = "Tiger Woods"
  ) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 14, face = "bold")
    ),
waffle(
  jordanspieth,
  rows = 5,
  colors = c("#18453B", "lightgrey")
) +
labs(
  x= "Jordan Spieth"
),
waffle(
  scottiescheffler,
  rows = 5,
  colors = c("#18453B", "lightgrey")
) +
labs(
  x= "Scottie Scheffler"
),
waffle(
  rorymcilroy,
  rows = 5,
  colors = c("#18453B", "lightgrey")
) +
 labs(
  x= "Rory McIlroy"
),
waffle(
  adamscott,
  rows = 5,
  title = "",
  xlab = "",
  colors = c("#18453B", "lightgrey")
) +
labs(
    x = "Adam Scott\n 1 square = 1 percent",
    caption="Source: PGA | Graphic by: Jenna Gustafson"
    )) 









While statistically it is easier to crown Tiger as the greatest of all time, there will always be the argument that players like Arnold Palmer or Jack Nicklaus are in the running for that title. Metrics are limited because technology at that time was extremely limited. Even though Nicklaus leads for the most accumulated major wins with 18 total, Tiger Woods is one of six players who has achieved a career grand slam. In fact, Tiger is the first and only player who has achieved “The Tiger Slam”, which is winning four consecutive majors in a row.
While players at the top are displaying a level of greatness that Tiger once had, the standard set by Tiger is not only about reaching the top, but also how long you can sustain your time there.

title: Is the Big Ten the most dominant conference in NCAA DI Volleyball?
text:
Over the past few seasons of Division I volleyball, there is a noticeable trend of powerhouse programs that have consistently held their position in the national rankings. Programs like Texas, Wisconsin and Nebraska have had a powerful presence near the top and prove their sustained excellence.
There is typically a majority of Big Ten teams that hold their places within the top 20. They also have a strong presence in the NCAA’s volleyball tournament every year with numerous Big Ten teams selected to compete.
Does the Big Ten dominate Division I volleyball?
Measuring RPI is a valid way of displaying the toughness of level of competitiveness teams face: that translates to being a good team.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(gt)
library(ggrepel)

RPI <- read_csv("newRPI.csv")


newRPI <- RPI |>
  mutate(
    Team = gsub("(AQ)", "", Team, fixed=TRUE)
  )


teamrpi <- newRPI |>
  mutate(
    Team = gsub("(AQ)", "", Team, fixed=TRUE)
  ) |>
  group_by(Team, Conference) |>
  summarise(
    avgrpi = mean(Adj.RPIValue, na.rm=TRUE), 
    avgrank = mean(`Adj.RPI Rank`, na.rm= TRUE)
  ) |>
  ungroup() |>
  top_n(20, wt= -avgrank) |>
  arrange(avgrank) 
 

teamrpi |>
  gt() |>
  cols_label(
   avgrpi = "Average RPI",
   avgrank = "Average Rank"
  ) |>
  tab_header(
    title = "One team in the Big Ten averaged within the top five teams from the past five seasons based on rank.",
    subtitle = "Two teams in the top five are part of the SEC and ACC."
  ) |> 
  tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |> 
  tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  ) |>
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Jenna Gustafson  |  **Source:** NCAA")
  )|>
  tab_style(
     locations = cells_column_labels(columns = everything()),
     style = list(
       cell_borders(sides = "bottom", weight = px(3)),
       cell_text(weight = "bold", size=12)
     )
   ) |>
  opt_row_striping() |> 
  opt_table_lines("none") |>
    fmt_percent(
    columns = c(avgrpi),
    decimals = 1) |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "#C5050C"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Team == "Wisconsin")
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "#E41C38"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Team == "Nebraska")
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "#C28E0E"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Team == "Purdue")
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "#7A0019"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Team == "Minnesota")
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "#154733"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Team == "Oregon")
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "#001E44"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Team == "Penn St.")
  ) 








One team in the Big Ten averaged within the top five teams from the past five seasons based on rank.


Two teams in the top five are part of the SEC and ACC.

By: Jenna Gustafson | Source: NCAA








However, averaging the RPI’s and ranks from the last five seasons and placing them in descending order based on their average rank, only one Big Ten team in within the top 5. Like all sports, teams will go through rough years. Wisconsin proved that between the 2023-2024 seasons. They lost seven games in 2024 but were rock solid in 2023 with only four.
While the Big Ten teams are not maintaining a strong presence in the


Code
ncaavb <- read_csv("ncaa_womens_volleyball_teams_2024.csv")

cleanncaavb <- ncaavb |> 
  select(conference, hit_pct, opponent_hit_pct) |>
  group_by(conference) |>
   summarise(
    avghitpct = mean(hit_pct), 
    avgopphitpct = mean(opponent_hit_pct)
  )


bigten <- cleanncaavb |>
  filter(conference == "Big Ten")

sec <- cleanncaavb |>
  filter(conference == "SEC")

bigtwelve <- cleanncaavb |>
  filter(conference == "Big 12")

acc <- cleanncaavb |>
  filter(conference == "ACC")

ivyleague <- cleanncaavb |>
  filter(conference == "Ivy League")

ovc <- cleanncaavb |>
  filter(conference == "OVC")

bigeast <- cleanncaavb |>
  filter(conference == "Big East")

theamerican <- cleanncaavb |>
  filter(conference == "The American")

wcc <- cleanncaavb |>
  filter(conference == "WCC")



ggplot() +
geom_point(data= cleanncaavb, aes(x= avghitpct, y= avgopphitpct), color = "lightgrey") +
  geom_point(data= bigten, aes(x= avghitpct, y= avgopphitpct), color = "#0088CE") +
  geom_point(data= sec, aes(x= avghitpct, y= avgopphitpct), color = "#22356B") +
  geom_point(data= bigtwelve, aes(x= avghitpct, y= avgopphitpct), color = "#C41230") +
  geom_point(data= acc, aes(x= avghitpct, y= avgopphitpct), color = "#013ca6") +
  geom_point(data= ivyleague, aes(x= avghitpct, y= avgopphitpct), color = "#006600") +
  theme_minimal() +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 0.2039252) + 
  geom_hline(yintercept = 0.2091922) +
  geom_text_repel(
    data=bigten, 
    aes(x=avghitpct, y=avgopphitpct, label=conference)
  ) +
  geom_text_repel(
    data=ivyleague, 
    aes(x=avghitpct, y=avgopphitpct, label=conference)
  ) +
  geom_text_repel(
    data=acc, 
    aes(x=avghitpct, y=avgopphitpct, label=conference)
  ) +
  geom_text_repel(
    data=bigtwelve, 
    aes(x=avghitpct, y=avgopphitpct, label=conference)
  ) +
  geom_text_repel(
    data=sec, 
    aes(x=avghitpct, y=avgopphitpct, label=conference)
  ) +
  annotate("rect", fill = "blue", alpha = 0.06, 
        xmin = 0.2039252, xmax = Inf,
        ymin = 0.195, ymax = 0.2091922) +
  geom_text(aes(x=.230, y=.198, label="Stronger offense and defense"), size=4, color= "blue") + 
  labs(
    title="The Big Ten has strong Offense and Defense.", 
    subtitle="The ACC has stronger defense .", 
    x="Avg Hit %", 
    y="Avg Opponent Hit %",
    caption = "Source: NCAA | By: Jenna Gustafson") + 
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 15, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=12), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    )











Code
RPI <- read_csv("newRPI.csv")


wlRPI <- RPI |>
  separate(WL, into=c("Wins", "Losses"), sep= "-") |>
   mutate(Wins = as.numeric(Wins), Losses = as.numeric(Losses))
  

newwlRPI <- wlRPI |>
 group_by(Season, Conference) |>
  summarise(
    totalwins = sum(Wins), 
    totallosses = sum(Losses),
    winpctline = totalwins/ (totalwins + totallosses)
  ) |>
  ungroup() |>
  group_by(Conference) 



acummulatedconfwinpercent <- newwlRPI |>
  group_by(Conference) |>
  summarise(
    confwinpct = mean(winpctline)
  )


winpctlinerpi <- newwlRPI |>
  group_by(Season, Conference) |>
  top_n(10, wt= -winpctline) |>
  arrange(desc(winpctline)) 
  


secline <- winpctlinerpi |> filter(Conference == "SEC") |> ungroup()

bigtenline <- winpctlinerpi |> filter(Conference == "Big Ten") |> ungroup() 

accline <- winpctlinerpi |> filter(Conference == "ACC") |> ungroup() 

bigtwelveline <- winpctlinerpi |> filter(Conference == "Big 12") |> ungroup()

ivyleagueline <- winpctlinerpi |> filter(Conference == "Ivy League") |> ungroup()



ggplot() +
  geom_line(data = winpctlinerpi, aes(x=Season, y= winpctline, group=Conference), color= "lightgrey") +
  geom_line(data = secline, aes(x=Season, y= winpctline, group=Conference), color= "#22356B") +
  geom_line(data = bigtenline, aes(x=Season, y= winpctline, group=Conference), color= "#0088CE") +
  geom_line(data = accline, aes(x=Season, y= winpctline, group=Conference), color= "#013ca6") +
  geom_line(data = bigtwelveline, aes(x=Season, y= winpctline, group=Conference), color= "#C41230") +
  geom_line(data = ivyleagueline, aes(x=Season, y= winpctline, group=Conference), color= "#006600") +
  geom_point(data = secline |> filter(Season == max(Season)), aes(x=Season, y= winpctline, group=Conference), color= "#22356B") +
  geom_point(data = bigtenline |> filter(Season == max(Season)), aes(x=Season, y= winpctline, group=Conference), color= "#0088CE") +
  geom_point(data = accline |> filter(Season == max(Season)), aes(x=Season, y= winpctline, group=Conference), color= "#013ca6") +
  geom_point(data = bigtwelveline |> filter(Season == max(Season)), aes(x=Season, y= winpctline, group=Conference), color= "#C41230") +
  geom_point(data = ivyleagueline |> filter(Season == max(Season)), aes(x=Season, y= winpctline, group=Conference), color= "#006600") +
  geom_text(data = secline |> filter(Season == max(Season)), aes(x=Season+.26, y= winpctline+.005, group=Conference, label=Conference), color= "#22356B") +
  geom_text(data = bigtenline |> filter(Season == max(Season)), aes(x=Season+.35, y= winpctline, group=Conference, label=Conference), color= "#0088CE") +
  geom_text(data = accline |> filter(Season == max(Season)), aes(x=Season+.26, y= winpctline+.004, group=Conference, label=Conference), color= "#013ca6") +
  geom_text(data = bigtwelveline |> filter(Season == max(Season)), aes(x=Season+.30, y= winpctline-.005, group=Conference, label=Conference), color= "#C41230") +  
  geom_text(data = ivyleagueline |> filter(Season == max(Season)), aes(x=Season+.37, y= winpctline-.005, group=Conference, label=Conference), color= "#006600") +  
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0.465, .625)) +
  scale_x_continuous(limits = c(2020, 2025)) + 
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(
    x="", 
    y="Win Percentage", 
    title="The Big Ten never finished with the highest winning percentage.", 
    subtitle="The ACC, SEC and Big 12 came out on top at least once over the past five seasons.", 
    caption="Source: NCAA | By: Jenna Gustafson"
    ) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 15, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=11), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot")
